title: Did any of the Beatles give Pete Best a monetary thank you for his contributions to the band? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not one of them gave Pete Best any monetary thank you.  In fact, Pete Best told Financial Review last April 2018 that until now none had even spoken to him since he was sacked about 56 years ago. Some rawness from that fateful day in 1962 still lingers on to him. He doesn't know who made the decision and it still rankles him that the band members didn't sack him themselves face-to-face. Best: “I'm not saying I'd change the outcome but at least give me the decency of being there and (letting me) confront them". After firing, John Lennon admitted they'd been cowards. While Sir Paul McCartney recalled in Beatles Anthology: “It was a big issue at the time, how we 'dumped' Pete. And I do feel sorry for him because of what he could have been on to. “But as far as we are concerned it was strictly a professional decision. But it was still very difficult.” However, even if Pete Best did not receive any monetary thank you from his former band mates, he did receive monetary reward for being a former Beatle. The release of the Beatles retrospective Anthology (1995) included a number of tracks with him on drums. He has remained tight-lipped about his subsequent share of the royalties but most estimates put it between £ 1 million and £ 4 million.  Thank you.

From Pete Best himself… “It came completely out of the blue. I knew ‘Anthology’ was coming out but I didn’t pay too much attention to it because I never figured that they would include me on it. But then I got the offer from Apple and low and behold, I ended up on 10 tracks which was great. As you say, after all these years it was a bit like ‘I must have been fairly important to get 10 tracks out of 60’. The bulk of the royalties came through when it was released and it was the icing on the cake after so many years. They keep drib drabbing in but you move on.” I believe it was Paul who said he insisted on using the early Pete Best on drums songs on the Anthology album, knowing he would finally earn Beatle level money from the album. Estimates indicate he made 9 million dollars or more. The Beatles recording success came after Best was let go by the group and Ringo Starr joined them.

I don’t think Pete Best was given anything freely by the Beatles. However, he successfully sued the Beatles in the 1960 (s) for defamation of character for a comment made in a Playboy magazine article. They said that one of the reasons they let Pete go was for pill popping. Pete received an undisclosed amount in an out of court settlement . In later years Pete received approximately $ 8 million for royalties from the Beatles Anthology album. This was not a free gesture, as Pete played on about 10 tracks and had a legal right to compensation. However, Paul Mccartney did call Pete personally and wish him well with the royalties cheque. This was the only time any Beatle said anything to Pete after he was let go.

Pete never received monetary compensation until the first Anthology CD1. Using 10 songs with his drumming on them, he had to be compensated legally. Estimates put his compensation at $9m US dollars, with drips of money coming in every year. Contrary to popular belief, The Beatles never forgot Pete after they fired him. He is included on the Sgt. Pepper album cover in a roundabout way. The medals on John’s uniform are Pete’s grandfather’s medals; John had remembered seeing them at Pete’s mother’s home when he was in the band. John asked their assistant, Neil Aspinall, who knew Pete, to go to his Mom’s house and ask permission to borrow them. She agreed on condition they were returned - they were. His Dad’s football trophy appears in the flower bed

There was another forgotten Beatle who made a fortune from Anthology. Its well known that the first record they ever cut was *In spite of all the Danger* ages before they recorded with Tony Sheriden, but it wasn’t cut professionally, it was done in a booth where you put a coin in a slot, and cut whatever sounds you made - many used such booths to get a record cut of them telling their spouse they loved them or similar home made things, So what wasn’t known was who had the record, none of the Beatles had it, and there were no second copies, but an early member of the Quarrymen kept it hidden for decades before the Anthology project, and when the time was right, sold it back to Paul for a fortune.

As far as I know he didn’t give any special contribution to the band. He only played on it and not very well. He not even was a Beatle. His mother was helpful, though. Because they could play on her pub called Casbah, or something like that. A very nice place, though really small. The band had others drummers besides Pete Best. I know that Pete was paid while he played with them. All of them were paid. So there was no need to give him monetary thank you. Maybe they did it, but it was not necessary. However, I heard they paid him something for another reason: Pete sued them. Too bad.

I’ve never heard about it if they did. But, I would not be surprised. John Lennon was apparently very generous to those close to him. I’ve read a ton about the Beatles, and talked with many in Liverpool. None has ever told me this. If you go to Liverpool, you can visit The Casbah, which was Pete’s mother’s house basement. You could ask there. Or, you could email Pete Best yourself. He might answer.

With respect to the initial installment of the Anthology series, I have heard that even though Best received royalties from its sale, that the remaining Beatles made sure that his image did not appear on the “mash-up” cover of the release. Sounds sort of petty at such a late date, but there were lots of issues between John, Paul George and Pete, not the least of which was his popularity with the girls who followed the earliest iteration of the band.

They didn’t directly. But Pete made a lot of money from both the live at BBC recordings that were done before Ringo replaced him and then from the various anthology releases which featured recordings from his time in the band.

I’ve never heard of them doing so, in fact, I’ve heard quite the opposite. In one interview, John said they were sick of Pete:  While I’m not too sure of the other’s opinions on Pete, I would think they would have a similar opinion.
He received royalties for the tracks he played on that appeared on Anthology 1.
No. But he made some money on The Beatle Anthology Recordings. Specifically The Decca Audition, as well as a few EMI sessions.
Quick answer: The Beatles didn’t do it, but since he appeared on the Anthology albums, he got a ton of residuals at that time.
